column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=Another method for cloning methylase and endonuclease genes is based on a colorimetric assay for DNA damage (see U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=When screening for a methylase, the plasmid library is transformed into the host E.coli strain such as AP1-200.
#Text=The expression of a methylase will induce the SOS response in an E.coli strain which is McrA+, McrBC+, or Mrr+.
#Text=The AP1-200 strain is temperature sensitive for the Mcr and Mrr systems and includes a lac-Z gene fused to the damage inducible dinD locus of E.coli.
#Text=The detection of recombinant plasmids encoding a methylase or endonuclease gene is based on induction at the restrictive temperature of the lacZ gene.
#Text=Transformants encoding methylase genes are detected on LB agar plates containing X-gal as blue colonies.
#Text=(Piekarowicz et al., Nucleic Acids Res. 19:1831-1835 (1991) and Piekarowicz et al., J.
#Text=Bacteriology 173:150-155 (1991)).
#Text=Likewise, the E.coli strain ER1992 contains a dinD1-Lac Z fusion but is lacking the methylation dependent restriction systems McrA, McrBC and Mrr.

#Text=In this system (called the "endo-blue" method), the endonuclease gene can be detected in the absence of it's cognate methylase when the endonuclease damages the host cell DNA, inducing the SOS response.
#Text=The SOS-induced cells form deep blue colonies on LB agar plates supplemented with X-gal.
#Text=(Fomenkov et al., Nucleic Acids Res. 22:2399-2403 (1994))
#Text=Sometimes the straight-forward methylase selection method fails to yield a methylase (and/or endonuclease) clone due to various obstacles, See, e.g., Lunnen et al., Gene 74(1):25-32 (1988).
#Text=One potential obstacle to cloning restriction-modification genes lies in trying to introduce the endonuclease gene into a host not already protected by modification.

#Text=If the methylase gene and endonuclease gene are introduced together as a single clone, the methylase must protectively modify the host DNA before the endonuclease has the opportunity to cleave it.
#Text=On occasion, therefore, it might only be possible to clone the genes sequentially, methylase first then endonuclease (see U.S.
#Text=Pat.

#Text=Another obstacle to cloning restriction-modification systems lies in the discovery that some strains of E.coli react adversely to cytosine or adenine modification; they possess systems that destroy DNA containing methylated cytosine (Raleigh and Wilson, Proc.
#Text=Natl.
#Text=Acad.
#Text=Sci.
#Text=USA 83:9070-9074 (1986)) or methylated adenine (Heitman and Model, J.
#Text=Bacteriology 196:3243-3250 (1987); Raleigh et al., Genetics 122:279-296 (1989); Waite-Rees et al., J.
#Text=Bacteriology 173:5207-5219 (1991)).
#Text=Cytosine-specific or adenine-specific methylase genes cannot be cloned easily into these strains, either on their own, or together with their corresponding endonuclease genes.
#Text=To avoid this problem it is necessary to use mutant strains of E. coli (McrA- and McrB- or Mrr-) in which these systems are defective.

#Text=An additional potential difficulty is that some restriction endonuclease and methylase genes may not express in E. coli due to differences in the transcription machinery of the source organism and E. coli, such as differences in promoter and ribosome binding sites.
#Text=The methylase selection technique requires that the methylase express well enough in E. coli to fully protect at least some of the plasmids carrying the gene.

#Text=Because purified restriction endonucleases, and to a lesser extent modification methylases, are useful tools for characterizing genes in the laboratory, there is a commercial incentive to obtain bacterial strains through recombinant DNA techniques that synthesize these enzymes in abundance.
#Text=Such strains would be useful because they would simplify the task of purification as well as provide the means for production in commercially useful amounts.
